title: eDNA Filtration and Preservation Protocol
content:
## eDNA Filtration and Preservation Protocol

### Purpose
This protocol describes the standard procedure for filtering and preserving eDNA samples collected from marine environments.

### Equipment Required
- Vacuum filtration apparatus (Nalgene or equivalent)
- 0.45μm pore size mixed cellulose ester (MCE) filters (47mm diameter)
- Sterile forceps
- 2mL cryovials
- Longmire buffer or 95% ethanol
- Vacuum pump (capable of -0.5 bar)
- Laminar flow hood (if available)

### Procedure

1. **Workspace Preparation**:
   - Clean workspace with 10% bleach solution
   - Expose to UV light for 30 minutes (if available)
   - Wear lab coat and fresh nitrile gloves

2. **Filtration Setup**:
   - Assemble sterile filter funnel
   - Place 0.45μm MCE filter on filter base using sterile forceps
   - Secure filter funnel and connect to vacuum

3. **Sample Filtration**:
   - Pour water sample into filter funnel
   - Apply vacuum (-0.3 to -0.5 bar)
   - Filter entire sample (typically 500mL - 1L)
   - Record filtration time and final volume filtered

4. **Filter Preservation**:
   - Using sterile forceps, fold filter in half (DNA side inward)
   - Place in labeled 2mL cryovial
   - Add 1mL Longmire buffer or 95% ethanol
   - Store at -20°C within 24 hours, -80°C for long-term storage

5. **Equipment Decontamination**:
   - Rinse filter apparatus with 10% bleach
   - Rinse 3x with ultrapure water
   - Allow to air dry

### Quality Control
- Process extraction blanks (unused filters) alongside samples
- Record lot numbers of all consumables
- Monitor vacuum pressure throughout filtration
- Replace filters if filtration time exceeds 30 minutes

### Troubleshooting
- If filter clogs: Use multiple filters per sample, record as fractions
- If vacuum insufficient: Check for leaks, replace tubing

### References
- CMLRE eDNA Laboratory Guidelines 2024
- Renshaw et al. (2015) Environmental DNA filtration optimization
